ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: An encompassing introductory to university writing, how to write a college-level research paper including the research process, proper citation methods, and the language and scope of topic. Also how to "deep-read" academic writing with proper attention to the meaning and specificity of the author's claims.
I became a better writer, learned how to write a longer and more open ended essay, learned research skills for finding scholarly information online, and became a better close reader
I learned the steps to writing a good college essay.

Reflection on childhood with focus on protectionism and individuality; grammar; analyzing texts for "gaps" in arguments; researching for and writing an academic paper; applying writing/analyzing ideas and techniques to other topics/modalities

I learned how to apply lessons from fictional works to the real world. I developed skills in close reading academic texts and finding connections between different ones. In my own writing, I learned how to put my ideas in conversation with related previous academic works by agreeing with what they said and building upon it or disagreeing and explaining why.

This class helped me build confidence in my writing ability and added writing skills and approaches to my arsenal such as using a variety of punctuation and effectively using counterarguments. Since this class focused on childhood and the ways that it's been constructed we also had many insightful discussions about toys, commercials, race, anti-adultism, and children's autonomy. As part of our final assignments we put into practice our research and analysis skills we had built throughout the semester.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
A definite strength was Professor Klemann, who was super understanding about this year's circumstances and evolved her teaching to the needs of students. 
One potential weakness was that the assignments weren't always clear in how they correlated to the overall goal; if that could be better communicated it would be much better!

I really liked how all of the material matched the topic so well, and felt coherent. The material is very relatable because we have all been children before. I wish the course emphasized grammar more. I feel my grammar needed work, and we learned shortly about grammar, but I don't know how much of it I retained
I believe Eng 114 is a very well designed course.  In taking this class, I was able to learn about a topic of great interest to me while learning how to write college-level essays.

strengths:
-the weekly blog posts make for unique, interesting conversations
-the essays are fun to right! they're open ended in a way that you can literally write about whatever you want which makes assignments a lot more interesting
-it's fun! the class is structured in a way that nothing really feels like work; the assignments are essentially just the essays which feel like researching and writing simply because you're interested in the topic

weaknesses:
-none?

The course is divided into to different sections each with a corresponding assignment to cap off the unit. I think this progression worked very well and each unit built upon your previous understanding. I know that for my class Professor Klemann included a section about differing dialects in language where we questioned the standard conventions or English. I appreciated that mini-unit a lot and think that it should be integrated into the class permanently.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Breakout rooms, outside speakers, and super available for office hours.
In class we did a virtual pop-up book presentation that went off without a hitch. We got it done pretty quickly and efficiently
I believe the transition to online worked very well in this course.

Succeeded: small breaks during class, engagement with own environment as a part of class discussion (e.g. find something important to you, grab something childish to eat, get your favorite childhood toy,...), use of Perusall for collaborative annotating of text

Could be improved: ...?
Although it was a small detail, I liked when the professor had us all stay unmuted during discussions so that it was easier to organically jump in, mimicking the flow of an in-person conversation.

I think that the adjustments made worked as seamlessly as possible. There was clear understanding of Zoom and all other software used. She was sure to make sure that students whether remote or on campus were able to fully participate in the class and was considerate of potential limitations.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to another student, especially a first-year who wants to learn an encompassing introduction to university-level writing. Additionally, if the topic of the course, such as childhood, is an area of interest for you, definitely take the course, as it introduces you to new observations and academic writing about the topic.
Yes I would, it was definitely not the easiest class, but it was an interesting class, and I have become a much better writer. I feel very prepared to finish my English credits

Absolutely!  English 114 is a spectacular introduction to college-level writing and the seminar format creates an intimate format that allows for good conversation and one on one help when necessary.  Additionally, Professor Klemann is a passionate, caring teacher who will do her all to help you improve your writing and your understanding of different concepts.

Yes!
Allows for self-reflection on (early life while building writing skills; engaging overarching topic (childhood) and subtopics (e.g. toys, food, social media...); demands creativity from students; lots of writing support made available

I could not possibly recommend this course more highly to another student. The conversations this class facilitated between my peers and I made me think of childhood as a whole as well as my personal childhood in a way I never had before. The professor was the most understanding I've ever had and really helped me develop as a writer. It was intellectually stimulating and a refreshing break from some of my other more dull classes.

Yes, I definitely would recommend this course to another student. I think about this class all the time now as I consume various from of media involving child development. I especially recommend this class earlier than later considering the writing component. It helps them feel more prepared for writing essays in the rest of their college career.
